I am with you guys on this.  Thanks for the input
Derek, Kenneth, and Colin.  The reason I originally
came to this group was because I asked about a program
I was trying to write for JRobots.
You are very right Colin, although I have not looked
too much into NEAT as of yet, we would have to pare
down some things to fit within the contraints of
JRobots.  In addition I found when I was working with
it the problem of trying to evolve a robot brain in
real-time. Which is why I am here.

--- Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> Derek James wrote:
> 
> >I've been looking at JRobots as a possible
> environment
> >(rather than coding everything from scratch):
> >
> >http://www.cfxweb.net/~jrobots/
> >
> >  
> >
> Hi Derek,  Strangely enough I had a brief  look into
> JRobots last week 
> with the intention of generating a bot using NEAT.
> The one headache I 
> can forsee is that the java code you submit cannot
> use any of the java 
> framework classes! So basically I think I would be
> looking at making a 
> port of Ken's neural network code into an minimal
> implementaion that is 
> written in raw Java. Which at first sounds easy but
> then think about the 
> lack of the Math functions! I don't know, maybe
> there IS a basic library 
> of essentials that I didn't pick up on.
> 
> Anyway your quest for an environment brings me back
> to one of my 
> original points which is - wouldnlt it be nice to
> have a central 
> repository of environment code. Prefereably modified
> to expose a 
> standard interface (or one of a set of interfaces)
> that we define for 
> use in EANN/GA type projects.
> 
> Colin.
> 
>
